'''Booker T. Laury''' (September 2, 1914 – September 23, 1995) was an [[United States|American]] [[boogie-woogie]], [[blues]], [[Gospel (music)|gospel]] and [[jazz]] [[pianist]] and [[singing|singer]].<ref name="AMG"/> Over his lengthy career, Laury worked with various [[musician]]s including [[Memphis Slim]] and [[Mose Vinson]]. He appeared in two films, but did not record his debut album until he was almost eighty years of age.<ref name="Jazz"/><ref name="IMDb"/>

==Biography==
'''Lawrence Laury''' was born in [[Memphis]], [[Tennessee]], and grew up with his lifelong friend, [[Memphis Slim]].<ref name="AMG"/> At the age of six, after helping his mother play the family's [[Reed organ|pump organ]], Laury learned to play the [[Keyboard instrument|keyboards]].  His [[Jazz|barrelhouse]] playing style, which he developed alongside Slim, was based on the influence gained from regular Memphis performers [[Roosevelt Sykes]], [[Sunnyland Slim]], and [[Speckled Red]].  In the early 1930s, and in the company of the younger [[Mose Vinson]], Slim and Laury began playing in local clubs.<ref name="Jazz"/>

In 1935, Sykes suggested to Laury and Slim that they relocated to [[Chicago]], with a view of obtaining a [[recording contract]].  Slim took up the advice, but Laury decided to remain in Memphis, where he played in gambling houses and clubs for decades. Laury had a large hand-width, which enabled him to span ten keys. His playing dexterity was such that, after losing one finger on his left hand following an accident with a [[circular saw]] in the 1950s, he was still able to play well. Based around Memphis' [[Beale Street]], as that area started to degenerate, Laury traveled around [[Tennessee]], [[Arkansas]] and [[Missouri]]. Despite differing fortunes, the friendship with Slim did not diminish over the years, up to Slim's death in 1988.<ref name="Jazz"/>

In the 1989 [[Dennis Quaid]] [[film]], ''[[Great Balls of Fire! (film)|Great Balls of Fire!]]'', the plot had a young [[Jerry Lee Lewis]] and [[Jimmy Swaggart]], look into a [[juke joint]] to see Laury playing "Big Legged Woman".  This attention led to Laury having the opportunity to record later in his life.<ref name="Jazz">{{cite web |url=http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/musician.php?id=8608 |title=Booker T. Laury |author=Johnson, Greg |publisher=Allaboutjazz.com |accessdate=October 27, 2010}}</ref>

Laury appeared in the 1991 [[documentary film]], ''[[Deep Blues: A Musical Pilgrimage to the Crossroads]]''.<ref name="IMDb">{{cite web|title=Deep Blues (1992)|url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0101697/|publisher=IMDb.com|accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref> In the film, Laury played "Memphis Blues" in his own living room.<ref name="Discogs">{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/artist/Booker+T.+Laury |title=Booker T. Laury Discography at Discogs |publisher=Discogs.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>

Laury finally recorded his debut album in his late seventies.<ref name="Jazz"/> In 1993, Bullseye Blues Records issued ''Nothin' But the Blues'', which simply incorporated Laury's voice and piano playing his own compositions.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|author=John Bush |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/booker-t-laury-mn0000098980/biography |title=Booker T. Laury | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref> The following year, Wolf Records released a [[live album]], containing [[concert]] recordings made in 1987.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/live-mw0000000576 |title=Live - Booker T. Laury | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>

Booker T. Laury died of [[cancer]], in September 1995 in Memphis, at the age of 81.<ref name="Jazz"/><ref name="Discogs"/> He has a brass note on Beale's Walk of Fame.<ref name="Flyer">{{cite web |url=http://www.memphisflyer.com/memphis/booker-t-laury/Content?oid=1308091 |title=Booker T. Laury |author= |publisher=Memphisflyer.com |accessdate=October 27, 2010}}</ref>
